title-group.article-title: The effect of β-cyclocitral treatment on the carotenoid content of transgenic Marsh grapefruit (Citrus paradisi Macf.) suspension-cultured cells

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The effect of β- cyclocitral treatment on the carotenoid content of transgenic Marsh grapefruit ( Citrus paradisi Macf.) suspension-cultured cells

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Citrus paradis
Citrus
Suspension-cultured cells Chemical elicitor β- yclocitral
Carotenoid
Provitamin A
ABSTRACT

This work reports the development of suspension culture system of transgenic Marsh grapefruit ( Citrus paradisi Macf., Rutaceae ) callus overexpressing bacterial phytoene synthase; and the use of this suspension culture to investigate the effects of β- cyclocitral on carotenoid content and composition. At a β- cyclocitral concentration of 0.5 mM and after ten days cultivation, analysis of the carotenoids showed a significant increase in the content of β-, α- carotene, and phytoene predominantly. The maximal increase in total provitamin A carotenoids content following β- cyclocitral application was ~2-fold higher than the control, reaching 245.8 μg/g DW. The trend for increased transcript levels of biosynthetic genes PSY and ZDS correlated with the enhancement of the content of these carotenes following β- cyclocitral treatment and GC-MS based metabolite profiling showed significant changes of metabolite levels across intermediary metabolism. These findings suggest that β- cyclocitral can act as a chemical elicitor, to enhance the formation of carotenes in citrus suspension-cultured cells (SCC), which could be utilized in studying the regulation of carotenoid biosynthesis and biotechnological application to the renewable production of nutritional carotenoids.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
2.1. Effect of β- cyclocitral treatment on the carotenoids content and composition of citrus suspension-cultured cells
sec.p: Once it was known which β- cc concentration induced the maximal levels of provitamin A carotenoids, the time course of provitamin A carotenoids production was analyzed in citrus SCC elicited with 0.5 mM β- cc. As shown in Fig. 4 , the content of all carotenoids, expect phytoene, was decreased from day 0 to 4th day. However, significantly increased accumulation of total and provitamin A carotenoids was observed by day 10. In contrast, the content of xanthophylls (violaxanthin and lutein) was always lower under β- cc treatment than control.

sec.title: 2.2. The effect of β- cyclocitral on the expression of genes involved in carotenoid formation and degradation in citrus suspension-cultured cells
2.3. Changes in intermediary metabolite pools associated with
sec.p: β- cyclocitral treatment of citrus transgenic suspension-cultured cells

sec.title: 3. Discussion
4. Conclusions
sec.p: In the present study, we report that β- cc treatment can be applied to enhance the contents of provitamin A carotenoids, phytoene and phytofluene in carotenoid-biofortified transgenic citrus SCC. These changes in carotenes contents were accompanied by increases in the expression of genes upstream of α/β- carotene biosynthesis and altered intermediary metabolite contents. These results highlight that the chemical elicitation strategy has a great potential to be utilized in improving valuable carotenoids production in plant cell factory. Furthermore, the suspension culture of carotenoid-biofortified transgenic citrus callus has a potential as a fundamental tool for the study of carotenoid regulation and small molecule/elicitor modulation of the pathway.

sec.title: 5.1. Plant materials and plant cell culture conditions
5.2. β- Cyclocitral treatments
sec.p:
Suspension-cultured cells were pre-cultivated in liquid media for 4 days prior to β- cyclocitral (β- cc) treatments. These suspension cells were cultured in 60 mL media containing 0 mM (control), 0.1 mM, 0.5 mM or 1 mM β- cc and harvested at 12 days after β- cc treatment. In addition, the suspension cells with 0.5 mM β- cc treatment were harvested at 0 days, 4th day, 7th day, 10th day and 14th day. Growth index (GI) of suspension-cultured cells under different treatment conditions was defined as GI = (final fresh weight of biomass - initial fresh weight of biomass)/initial fresh weight of biomass (
).

sec.title: 5.3. Carotenoid profile
5.4. Quantitative Real-time PCR
5.5. GC-MS based metabolite profiling
5.6. Statistical analysis
sec.p: All the data are presented as the mean ± SE (standard deviation of the mean) of three biological replications unless stated otherwise. The statistical analysis of data was carried out using the Microsoft Excel program. One-way ANOVA and Student’ s t-tests were used to calculate significant difference of expression level of carotenoid pathway genes in suspension-cultured cells between treatment and control. Multiple comparisons of carotenoid content were performed by using SAS version 8 (SAS Institute, Cary, NC). The Heml 1.0 software was used for heatmap displaying of the metabolites data from GC-MS analysis.

sec.title: Declaration of competing interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.

sec.title: Acknowledgements
sec.p: This work was supported in part through the National Key Research and Development Program of China (2018YFD1000200), European Union Framework Program DISCO (from DISCOvery to products: a nextgeneration pipeline for the sustainable generation of high-value plant products; Project 613513), the Biotechnology and Biological Sciences Research Council OPTICAR Project (optimisation of tomato fruit carotenoid content for nutritional improvement and industrial exploitation), National Natural Science Foundation of China (No. 31930095, 31630065) and a China council scholarship. We greatly appreciate Hongbo Cao, Kit Liew, Rapacz Elzbieta, Chris Gerrish and Karl Crosby for their excellent technical assistance.

sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https://doi. org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2020.112509.
